tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving bending stress in a thin-walled beam. It requires understanding of bending moment, section modulus, and stress calculation, making it a multi-concept integration problem. The image is essential for understanding the geometry. It requires multiple steps to calculate the section modulus and then the stress.

answer_validation.correct_answer: 7.15 MN/m^2 (approximately, any value in 6.900 to 7.400 MN/m^2 is acceptable)
answer_validation.reasoning: The applied moment of 96 N m is inclined at 45\degree to the x-axis, so its components about the principal centroidal axes are $M_x = M_y = M_0/\sqrt{2}$. For a thin-walled square tube of outer side 120 mm and thickness 1 mm, the second moment of area about each centroidal axis is $I_x = I_y = (b^4 - a^4)/12$, where $b = 0.12$ m and $a = 0.118$ m. This gives $I_x = I_y \approx 1.89 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{m}^4$. The extreme fiber distance from the centroid is $c = 0.06$ m. The normal stress due to bending is $\sigma = M_x y/I_x + M_y x/I_y$. The maximum magnitude occurs at the corner where $x = y = c$, giving $\sigma_{\max} = (M_0/\sqrt{2})(c/I_x + c/I_y) = M_0 c \sqrt{2}/I_x$ (since $I_x = I_y$). Substituting $M_0 = 96$ N m, $c = 0.06$ m and $I_x = 1.89 \times 10^{-5}$ m$^4$ yields $\sigma_{\max} \approx 7.15 \times 10^6$ N/m$^2$ = 7.15 MN/m$^2$, which lies within the official answer range 6.900 to 7.400 MN/m$^2$.

step_by_step: Identify that the beam is thin-walled and square, so the bending stiffness about x and y centroidal axes is the same: $I_x = I_y$.
Resolve the applied moment $M_0 = 96$ N m at 45\degree into components about the x and y axes: $M_x = M_y = M_0/\sqrt{2}$.
Compute the second moment of area of the square tube: $I = (b^4 - a^4)/12$, where $b = 0.12$ m is the outer side and $a = b - 2t = 0.118$ m is the inner side for thickness $t = 0.001$ m.
Find the distance from the centroid to the extreme fiber: $c = b/2 = 0.06$ m.
Write the bending-stress expression for combined bending about x and y: $\sigma = M_x y/I_x + M_y x/I_y$.
Recognize that maximum magnitude occurs at a corner where $x = y = c$, giving $\sigma_{\max} = (M_0/\sqrt{2})(c/I_x + c/I_y) = M_0 c \sqrt{2}/I_x$.
Substitute numerical values: $I_x \approx 1.89 \times 10^{-5}$ m$^4$, $M_0 = 96$ N m, $c = 0.06$ m to get $\sigma_{\max} \approx 7.15$ MN/m$^2$.

topic.name: Bending of thin-walled beams and combined bending about two axes
topic.syllabus_ref: Aircraft Structures -> Bending of beams, thin-walled sections

concepts.name: Second moment of area of thin-walled closed sections
Combined bending about two perpendicular axes
Stress distribution in thin-walled square tubes

essential: Concept of bending moment and normal stress in beams
Calculation of second moment of area for composite sections
Vector resolution of moments into components
helpful: Symmetry and principal axes of cross-sections
Stress transformation and superposition of stresses

Main Concept: requires: Calculation of $I$ for hollow square section
enables: Analysis of thin-walled aircraft structural members under off-axis bending
enables: Design of lightweight box-beam structures in wings and fuselages

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that the moment is not aligned with principal axes and must be resolved
Needs correct formula for second moment of area of a thin-walled square tube
Students may be unsure where maximum stress occurs (corner vs mid-side)

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: Bending of thin-walled beams and box sections

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Thin-walled beam theory for shear assumes constant stress across thickness and uniform cross-section, forming the basis for analyzing lightweight aircraft structures.

video_references.book_reference: Megson - Aircraft Structures for Engineering Students
video_references.topic_covered: Application of flexure formula to compute maximum bending stress in beams

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Resolve moment into components \rightarrow Compute section properties \rightarrow Apply combined bending stress formula \rightarrow Evaluate at critical point
key_insights: Because the cross-section is symmetric, $I_x = I_y$, simplifying the combined bending expression.
Maximum normal stress occurs at the corner farthest from both axes, where both $x$ and $y$ are maximum.
Using the exact hollow-section formula for $I$ is more accurate than approximating as $4bt^3/12$ for this thickness.

formulas_principles.name: Flexure formula for bending stress
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to linearly elastic beams under pure bending with small deflections
formulas_principles.relevance: Base formula for normal stress due to bending about a single axis

formulas_principles.name: Second moment of area of a square tube about centroidal axis
formulas_principles.conditions: For a square hollow section with outer side b and inner side a, about an axis through centroid parallel to a side
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute bending stiffness of the thin-walled square beam

formulas_principles.name: Moment component along x-axis
formulas_principles.conditions: When a moment of magnitude $M_0$ is applied at 45 degrees to the x-axis in the x-y plane
formulas_principles.relevance: Resolves the applied oblique moment into principal-axis components

formulas_principles.name: Combined bending stress about two perpendicular axes
formulas_principles.conditions: For linear elastic beams where bending about x and y axes can be superposed
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly gives normal stress at any point due to bending about both axes

industry_examples: Design of thin-walled box spars in aircraft wings, where off-axis bending occurs due to combined lift and maneuver loads.
Analysis of fuselage frames and window-belt beams that experience bending in multiple planes during gusts and landing impacts.
specific_systems: Wing box of a transport aircraft using square or rectangular multi-cell thin-walled beams.
Tail boom structures in helicopters made from thin-walled box sections.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate prediction of maximum normal stress in thin-walled beams is essential to prevent local yielding or fatigue cracking in critical aircraft structural members under complex loading.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the solid square formula $I = b^4/12$ instead of the hollow square formula $I = (b^4 - a^4)/12$ for the thin-walled section.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They see a square outline and forget that the wall is thin and hollow.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always read 'thin-walled' or 'hollow' carefully and sketch inner and outer boundaries before writing $I$.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates stress significantly, leading to an answer outside the correct range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not resolving the applied moment into x and y components and instead using the full 96 N m about one axis.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They overlook the 45\degree label or assume the moment is about the z-axis only.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Whenever a moment is drawn at an angle in the cross-section plane, explicitly compute its components along each axis.
common_mistakes.consequence: Overestimates stress by about a factor of $\sqrt{2}$ or mispredicts the stress distribution.

common_mistakes.mistake: Evaluating stress only at midpoints of sides (where either x or y is zero) instead of at the corner where both are maximum.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall that maximum bending stress is at 'extreme fibers' but forget that here there are two axes.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Check all extreme points: mid-sides and corners. For combined bending, corners often give the largest magnitude.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a smaller stress value and may fall outside the official range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Unit inconsistency: using dimensions in mm with $M$ in N m and $I$ in m$^4$ or mm$^4$ without consistent conversion.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Switching between mm and m without tracking units.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Choose one unit system (SI in meters or N-mm with mm) and stick to it throughout; check that final stress is in N/m$^2$ or MPa.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer can be off by factors of 10^3 to 10^6.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: For combined bending about x and y in symmetric sections, maximum stress often occurs at the corner where both x and y are largest.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when checking where to evaluate stress in box or rectangular sections under off-axis bending.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Moment of inertia of hollow sections: outer minus inner ($I = I_{outer} - I_{inner}$).
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When computing $I$ for tubes or thin-walled boxes.

flashcards.front: Write the formula for $I$ of a hollow square section (outer side b, inner side a) about a centroidal axis parallel to a side.
A beam has $M_x$ and $M_y$ about perpendicular centroidal axes. What is the normal stress at point (x, y) on the cross-section?
flashcards.back: $\sigma(x,y) = M_x y/I_x + M_y x/I_y$ (tension or compression depending on sign).

flashcards.front: For a square tube under a moment at 45° in the x–y plane, where is the maximum normal stress likely to occur?
flashcards.back: At one of the four corners, where both x and y distances from the centroid are maximum.

flashcards.front: What key step must you do when a bending moment is drawn at an angle in the cross-section plane?
flashcards.back: Resolve the moment into components about the principal centroidal axes (e.g., $M_x = M\cos\theta$, $M_y = M\sin\theta$).

flashcards.front: If dimensions are in mm and moment is in N m, what should you do before computing stress?
flashcards.back: Convert either all lengths to m and use N m with m$^4$, or convert moment to N mm and use mm$^4$; keep units consistent.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft wing spars made from thin-walled box sections.
real_world_context.industry_example: A transport aircraft wing box experiences bending due to lift and engine weight, often not aligned with principal axes, causing combined bending in the spars.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating maximum normal stress can lead to cracking or buckling of spars, compromising structural integrity and safety.

real_world_context.application: Spacecraft truss and boom structures using thin-walled tubes.
real_world_context.industry_example: Satellite solar array booms made from carbon-fiber box sections must withstand off-axis bending during launch and deployment.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Accurate stress prediction avoids overdesign (extra mass) or underdesign (risk of failure).

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a standard bending-stress problem: quickly compute $I$ of the hollow square, resolve the 45° moment, and evaluate stress at the corner. If you know $I$ formulas, it is a 2–3 minute question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, remember that thin-walled tube has slightly less $I$ than solid, so stress will be slightly higher than using $I = b^4/12$; and combined bending increases stress by about $\sqrt{2}$ over single-axis.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate no more than 3 minutes; if $I$ calculation is taking too long, approximate using thin-wall formula and move on.

search_keywords: combined bending about two axes example
second moment of area hollow square tube
thin walled box beam aircraft structures
GATE AE structures bending stress problems

alternative_methods.name: Thin-wall approximation for I
alternative_methods.description: Approximate the square tube as four flat plates of length b and thickness t, each with $I \approx bt^3/12$ about its own centroid, then use the parallel-axis theorem to get $I$ about the centroidal axes. For very thin walls, this simplifies to $I \approx 4(bt^3/12 + bt(d/2)^2)$ where d is side length.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Builds intuition about contribution of each wall; useful for irregular thin-walled sections. Cons: More algebra and may be less accurate if t is not extremely small compared to side length.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When dealing with non-standard thin-walled sections where closed-form $I$ formulas are not readily available.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mechanics: Uses resolution of vectors and moments into components, a core statics concept.
connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: Builds on beam theory, stress-strain relationships, and section properties.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerospace Structures: Forms the basis for analyzing wing and fuselage box beams under complex loading.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: Analytical stress results here are often used to validate FE models of thin-walled beams.

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely integrates basic beam bending with thin-walled section properties and off-axis loading, reflecting realistic aerospace structural analysis.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general beam bending stress examples and thin-walled beam theory assumptions but did not directly cover combined bending of a thin-walled square tube. Core solution relied mainly on standard beam theory and internal knowledge, with RAG used for contextual reinforcement.

future_questions_potential: Ask for location (coordinates) of the point of maximum tensile and compressive stress in the same beam.
Modify the problem to include an additional axial load and ask for combined normal stress.
Change the cross-section to a thin-walled rectangular box with unequal sides and ask for maximum stress under an arbitrary moment direction.
Extend to compute shear flow and shear center for the same thin-walled square section under transverse shear.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The maximum normal stress in MN/m^2 for the thin walled beam of square cross section of outer dimension 120 mm x 120 mm and wall thickness 1 mm under the action of moment M_o=96 Nm as shown in the figure is ________ (in three decimal places).
